A major fire in Southern California has destroyed more than a hundred homes and dozens of other buildings in San Bernardino County since it started on Tuesday.
The so-called Blue Cut fire has now spread across 37,000 acres in the area.
It's the latest in a string of fires that have plagued California as it battles a five-year drought.
Firefighters there say there used to be a fire season in the state, but now they have to be on alert all year round.
Mike Mohler is a battalion chief with the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection, and he joins us now from San Bernardino.
Thanks so much for being with us.
Thank you for having me.
Can you give us a sense of the severity of this fire?
Can you describe the damage you've seen?
Within 24 hours, this fire grew to 30,000 acres, and that's just the conditions that we're seeing statewide.
Unfortunately, this fire moves so fast that at this point we have over - well over a hundred structures that have been destroyed.
We're happy to report, though, as of now there were no injuries to civilians.
So I guess this is the big question.
Why is it that the fires in California are becoming increasingly more destructive and more frequent?

Well, even though Northern California did have some precipitation this winter, five years of drought, the fuel moistures are no longer there, meaning that there's no moisture in the actual vegetation.
And when we get these fires now, we are seeing what we call now explosive fire growth.
And now the explosive fire growth statewide is unfortunately the new normal.
We're seeing fire conditions that are unprecedented.
In my 22 years, I haven't seen fire move like I have this year.
I was with a 31-year veteran on the Blue Cut fire.
He said the same thing.
I've never seen it like this.
I imagine this puts financial pressure on your department.
How do you pay for it?
Well, it does.
We have what we call the Emergency Fund, or the E-Fund, that we use to battle these large fires.
And right now, that's what we use to pay for them.
And then if that fund, at some point, we're getting close or, you know, we go over expenditure, we can go back to the legislators to increase the funding.
But I think for your listeners to know that in the state of California there's always going to be funding and there will always be firefighting equipment there if we do have a large fire.
Have people who live in these places that are particularly prone to fires - have you seen behaviors start to change?
Have you seen residents start to move out of these particularly dangerous places?
No.
In fact, the exact opposite.
We're actually seeing more homes and tracks being built in these areas.
And that brings me to another point - is, you know, a lot of these people that live especially in the Blue Cut area didn't evacuate, the reason being is they - well, we've seen fire.
We live here.
Well, now the way that fires are moving, people can't stay in their homes anymore.
And if they're asked to evacuate, they need to.
When firefighters are seeing fire growth that they've never seen, you only have seconds to get out of your home if you wait.

What does this mean in the medium and long term for fire departments in California when you think about this drought and the extension of what used to be a very discreet period of time in the year that was the fire season?
Now, as you said, it's the new normal.
Every month is the fire season.
It lasts almost for 12 months.
Well, I think what we're seeing now - departments are going to have to look at different staffing models, you know?
And in the wintertime when we used to have fire season, when we would get rain, some of our brush engines and stations, we would down staff and move those firefighters to other areas.

That's not the case anymore, that - and we're going to have to look at different staffing models, additional equipment for year-round operations and year-round response just to battle those types of fires.
Battalion Chief Mike Mohler with Cal Fire speaking to us from San Bernardino where the Blue Cut fire has been raging.
Thanks so much for taking the time.
Thank you.

Metro Atlanta receives its water from the Chattahoochee watershed.
It's basically the Chattahoochee River.
Its water is actually north of the city, basically in the Appalachian Mountains.
And it is a little outside of the metro-Atlanta local area, but we have several reservoirs, and we actually pipe the water into the city and distribute it to local residents.
Are there people fighting over this water?
The same water, because, for example, living in Los Angeles, water is incredibly politicized.
So, is that the same here?
The East has different water rights, legally, and Gil could probably speak to that.
But basically, the thing that causes communities to fight over water is that they are not managed based on their watersheds.
They are actually managed based on their municipal boundaries.
And so, unfortunately, what that does is, when you see growth, and when you see urban sprawl, in some cases, you cause a strain on that finite water source.
Gil, what do you think about the politicization, or I guess, the ""turf war"" over water?
Well, these wars have been going on here in the Southeast now for 18 years.
We have been fighting with Alabama and Florida over the Chattahoochee River and some of the other river basins in this area.
And again, as Darryl said, water doesn't follow political boundaries.

It follows natural basins, and when you have a city that is the size of Atlanta that straddles five different river basins and you have all this political lines in play, then it makes it very difficult to manage the water in a sustainable way.
What are we actually talking about?
If you have - for example, getting down to a three-month reserve sounds pretty tough.
But was there - did people buckle down?
I guess what I am saying, here in Atlanta, did people buckle down, stop watering their lawns, stop taking showers every day?
Or did people go around business as usual saying, ""Eh!"" you know?
No.
At the local level, Atlantans were very pro-active and, it was significant water savings and water conservations.

I think that's the problem with addressing some of the recent legislation is that, you know, once the residents stepped up, and met the need and met the Governor's call for a closer to a ten-percent reduction, some feel as though they were penalized in that revenue, that hoped to come from business as usual was not there, and so now we are looking at infrastructure costs, and how can we pay for them?
Gil, what about that, you know, if water is a commodity that people and business pay for, and then those revenues go down.
Are these municipalities, including Atlanta, really trapped, in terms of making improvements in infrastructure?
Well, one of the big losses of water that we see throughout the Southeast, and certainly here in Atlanta, is water that is lost out of these aging infrastructures systems.

You have leaky pipes and aging treatment facilities, and it does require a conscious allocation of money to fix those, and you have utilities that rely on water-rate charges coming in to help offset that cost.
And so there is an effect that these utilities can feel.

But it is a preventable problem, if you have state level policies, and the willingness from leadership to reallocate funding and restructure pricing, so that you can continue to conserve and still fix you infrastructure.
It is - it can be a win-win situation, but unfortunately, a lot of the cities just aren't set up that way.
Darryl, when people used the term ""Hotlanta,"" they are referring to culture, but it also gets very steamy here in the summer.
Yes.

And if you are in places like Baltimore, my hometown, or you know, in the Bronx, you see people flipping open the hydrants and all the kids having fun, but that is an incredibly inefficient way to use water.
When you talked about urban communities in particular, are there attempts to do some outreach that really speak to folks in urban communities?
Definitely, as you pointed out, in most servicing centers, providing water is actually a public-health concern.
You know, you are actually trying to take care of the fact that water or the lack thereof, access to water, provides a pathway to all kind of problems.
And so, you know, definitely municipalities is going to want to have some access to water.
So the governor, kind of, in that same thing, is going to allow for public pools to be filled and that kind of thing.
But I also think, at the, you know, the residence level, we're going to have to think on other ways to address conservation, and possibly protection of our water resources.
There are a lot of things that we can do in our homes that will affect protecting our creeks, and streams, and eventually our river.
Gil, you're - Georgia is involved in a lawsuit with Alabama and Florida over water rights, and you are very involved.
Tell us about this strife between those states specifically, and how Georgia is trying to fix that issue.
Well, it's - the fight has arisen over the management of several large reservoirs in Georgia, both Lake Lanier on the Chattahoochee and Lake Allatoona on the Coosa System.
And Alabama and Florida are downstream states and they expect a certain amount of water to come down to sustain their ecology, and their businesses, and their public health.
And Georgia is maintaining that if - because the waters are in its state and it has certain right to those waters.

And it really comes down to looking at whether each state has its house in order in terms of management, and unfortunately, we have a history of waiting until droughts and crisis to really start addressing water.
And you know, the legislature says uh-oh, you know, we haven't done anything.
We need to step up a little bit, and we just can't do that sustainably going forward, and Florida and Alabama both have their own water challenges.
I think all three states can improve water management to different degrees.
But Georgia certainly has a long way to go.
That's right.
What about farm versus urban?
Because in some parts of the country, that's an issue, too.
It is, like, how much water goes to irrigation?
How much water goes to natural resources, like wetlands?
How much water goes to cities?
What do you think about that?
Well, it's a good question, and I should point out actually that it is not just Florida and Alabama that are downstream in this case.
It is a lot of southern Georgia, cities like Columbus, and going all the way down to Bainbridge in south Georgia, and also a lot of farm communities.
And agriculture does account for a lot of water use, particularly in south Georgia, and they've had problems in the past with using too much of a finite resource and drawing down aquifers.

They are making improvements, but there really is not a whole lot on the books in terms of kind of mandating a progress towards conservation in the agricultural community, and that is something we are concern about in addition to the municipal and industrial water use.
Darryl, this is becoming an international issue, you know, water as turf rights or something, that are causing disputes between different nations.
Are you optimistic or pessimistic, that in Georgia and in the United States, we are going to be able to work out our differences, without getting into too rough of a situation?
I am optimistic.
It is hard not to kind of wax into that whole science-fiction, doomsday scenario when you view water as strictly a free-market commodity.
But fortunately, it is not just a free-market commodity.
It is a utility, and so there has to be some aspect of public access.

And so when you look at it in terms of, you know, despite creating distribution, so that costs don't rise, that people will have access to good, clean, quality water, if we do a few simple, basic things to protect it.
Gil, do you think that water is a human right?
There is a lot of debate over whether that is the case.
I do.
I view water as a public resource.
It is something that our government is charged with managing, so that we all have enough water to use, and that it is affordable, and plentiful.
And you know, as I have said, our leadership, at this point, has fallen short, I think, in a lot of ways in insuring that we continue to have that right.
